content:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90044 is beta-nominated but not yet accepted, and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/91220 is the version of it up for actual backport (smaller, I believe). I'm hoping to get the artifacts for stable built today, so would be great to get a decision here -- I'm going to go dig to see if it was discussed in the meeting last wednesday.

cc @pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser
That looks familiar. I think it was discussed. But the conversation may be confusing or at least confused
discussion starting here https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.5D.202021-11-24.20.2354818/near/262607266
but it looks like it was only nominated, not accepted, perhaps?
Looks like we decided to backport? https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.5D.202021-11-24.20.2354818/near/262608943
hm, yes
I guess just labels not updated?
Seems like it yeah.
I think I'd rather take #90044 than #91220 personally...

#90044 can't be taken as is because it builds on #90623, which is not in beta. Otherwise I would not have bothered with #91220. See https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90044#issuecomment-978040731 and so on.
hm
I'm happy with either but would love to not have to make the decision :)

#90044 is just not a possible choice, because it cannot be merged into beta as is. So the choice is rather 1) #90044 + #90623 (+ whatever else might be necessary to make #90623 merge cleanly) or 2) #91220 or 3) nothing and living with --target aarch64-unknown-linux-musl failing.
@Wesley Wiser are you ok with #91220?
Ah ok. Yeah I'm fine with 91220
sounds good, will roll it in then
Thanks @Hans Kratz for the explanation!
Sorry that we are cutting it so close with this one. Next time I will be more aware of the release schedule and push to get a critical fix accepted and backported earlier.
no worries, not uncommon (unfortunately...) :)

I am also sorry I didn't think about the timing issue more attentively. Is there a cheatsheet, guide, or calendar I can look at when reviewing PRs to fix regressions (by code I may have signed off on or written :sweat_smile: ) to make sure they are resolved before we hit the next cut?
forge.rust-lang.org has a table with the release dates
But it's "just" 6 weeks, so you can also add calendar events if you want (I have one for release date itself)
Nice.
Do we have a sample preflight checklist for PRs?
I'm not sure I understand.
I think there was a hackmd with reviewer guidelines floating around, but that seems rather separate from this
for regressions generally the important thing is to get things tagged beta-nominated ~immediately, that gets them on the radar .
Yeah, just reviewer guidelines, really.
Which should apparently include "if regression then make sure this gets tagged beta-nominated"
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/444
(doesn't contain this but is sort of the right theme. some links from there to other, similar, docs too)

Also, for things that are critical, consider starting a thread in #t-compiler, bringing them up during the weekly compiler team triage meeting or even PM'ing Felix or I if you're just not sure what the correct protocol is. I know we'd both rather get a few PMs than let important issues slip under the radar. :smile:

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90788 is not yet backported (I just marked as beta-nom). AFAICT, the regression is introduced by https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/68528 which is quite old, so this is not recent

but I noted the comment suggesting beta backport so wanted to raise it (we have time to rebuild artifacts if necessary).

cc @Wesley Wiser @pnkfelix
not sure if we want to backport this change
We discussed this during last week's triage meeting and decided not to backport IIRC
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.5D.202021-11-24.20.2354818/near/262604287
sounds good
Thanks for checking!
(would be great to leave an explicit comment in the future :)

simulacrum said:

(would be great to leave an explicit comment in the future :)

yeah will do! Sorry about that @simulacrum
